context.text: Reference [14] presents an algorithm to estimate synchronizer performance.
The results presented in the previous section were obtained using the metastability analysis technique presented in [14].

The key idea in the analysis scheme in [14] is that the behavior of the circuit for any point between \$p0\$ and \$p1\$ can be estimated by linear interpolation of the behaviors from \$p0\$ and \$p1\$, and this estimate is quite accurate for small time intervals up until the original behaviors have diverged significantly.

The algorithm from [14] computes this width by finding the width at the \${\rm k}^{{\rm th}}\$ voltage interval, and multiplying it by the linear factors that it has computed that relate each voltage interval to its successor.
By using bisection with restarts as described above, the algorithm from [14] avoids the numerical limitations of traditional bisection based approaches.
To use the algorithm from [14] in an industrial setting, we made a few practical modifications.
First, the implementation of the algorithm in [14] is written entirely in MATLAB using typical, textbook models for transistors and other circuit elements.

Checks #1 and #2 provide reasonable estimates of \$\tau\$ and Tw(nom) that can be used to cross-check the results obtained from a more detailed analysis method such as the algorithm we have used that is reported in [13], [14].

The algorithm from [14] provides accurate values for the \${\rm Ts}i\$, Alternatively, practical estimates of the \${\rm Ts}i\$ values can be obtained from simulations of each latch pair \$i\$ and \$i+1\$, to find the amount of settling time between these two latches before the q output of latch \$i+1\$ experiences added delay.

context.text: PSF is modeling the susceptibility of a cell in a memory array to the contents and transitions of all other cells [1]–[2][3].

However, the most common neighborhoods are the Type-1 and Type-2 neighborhoods [1], [2].

Aiming to detect in common and at an optimum test application time, active, passive and static NPSFs (APSNPSFs) with respect to the Type-1 and Type-2 neighborhoods, every possible neighborhood with base cell every cell of the memory array should be written with the patterns of an Eulerian sequence [2].

Moreover, two methods to further accelerate the test application time have been adopted for the write operation of the test sequence in the memory array, the tiling and the two-groups methods [2], [5].

Focusing at the physical design of the memory array in Fig. 2 it is easy to realize that none of the neighbor cells (the immediate adjacent cells with physical proximity) of any cell in the memory array (e.g. cell-0) belongs to the same word-line with this cell, as it is supposed in the various NPSF types in the open literature [2].

Thus, applying a test to locate APSNPSF algorithm, like the TLAPNPSF1T and TLAPNPSF2T algorithms in [2], we can detect and locate all active, passive and static NPSFs related to the Δ-Type neighborhood with a cost of 82n operations, where n is the number of cells in the memory array.
